document.masterDocTitle: A new cryptic species allied to Plestiodon japonicus (Peters, 1864) (Squamata: Scincidae) from eastern Japan, and diagnoses of the new species and two parapatric congeners based on morphology and DNA barcode

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new cryptic species allied to Plestiodon japonicus (Peters, 1864) (Squamata: Scincidae) from eastern Japan, and diagnoses of the new species and two parapatric congeners based on morphology and DNA barcode

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Scincus quinquelineatus : Temminck & Schlegel, 1838 , p. 99
, p. 193 (in part)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Plestiodon quinquelineatus : Duméril & Bibron, 1839, p. 707
(in part)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Plestiodon quinquelineatum : Gray, 1845 , p. 91
(in part); Bleeker, 1858, p. 205 (in part)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. A moderate-sized
Plestiodon
(ca. 60–90 mm SVL for adults) similar to
P. finitimus
. This species differs from
P. barbouri
in usually having 24–30 MSRs. The Izu Peninsular population of this species differs from
P. finitimus
and
P. japonicus
in usually having a large postnasal contacting with the posterior loreal ( Fig. 2B ), or sometimes lacking a postnasal ( Fig. 2C ), and having a slightly smaller number of MSRs (24 and 26 in similar frequencies, range, 22–26). The Izu Insular populations, except that of Izuoshima Island, differ from
P. finitimus
and
P. japonicus
in lacking the bifurcating pattern of the dorsal yellowish stripe on the juvenile head. The insular populations differ from
P. finitimus
and
P. japonicus
in having a larger number of MSRs (usually 28 or 30), with geographic variation.

DNA barcode.
The nucleotide sequence of the 658 bp fragment of the mitochondrial COI gene (the standard barcode region) from five specimens from two localities (including the type locality) was determined and deposited in the GenBank database ( Accession No. JN089942 –46)
.

Variation. The Izu Peninsular and Izuoshima Island populations have similar color patterns during ontogeny and sexual dimorphism, including the breeding season coloration, to
P. finitimus
, although adults of this species have a slightly darker and greenish dorsal color and reddish brown dorsolateral color compared with
P. finitimus
and
P. japonicus
. Juveniles of the other populations have no bifurcating pattern on the head and a faded blue tail, and tend to change their color pattern at an earlier stage of ontogeny ( Taylor 1936 ; Hikida 1979b ;
Kuriyama et al. 2006
;
Kuriyama et al. 2009a
).

Note. The populations on three islands (Miyakejima, Hachijojima, and Aogashima Islands) have been threatened by predation pressure from the artificially introduced Japanese weasel
Mustela itatsi Temminck
( Hasegawa 1999 ) and are listed in the national red data book of Japan ( Hasegawa & Ota 2000 ).
